intro: Umbilicus vulgaris subsp. horizontalis, commonly known as the horizontal bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–30 cm, featuring upright, branching stems covered in soft, hairy foliage. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale blue, often blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and arranged alternately along the stems, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This species is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges.
